title: Inside Politics — Political News
text:
Inside Politics

Related Articles

Federal judge blocks Georgia 'heartbeat' abortion law A federal judge on Tuesday temporarily blocked Georgia's restrictive new abortion law from taking effect, following the lead of other judges who have blocked similar measures in other states. Shares

Facebook shuts down professor's page debunking Warren's Native American ancestry claims Facebook has removed an Ivy League professor's 6-year-old page, Elizabeth Warren Wiki, saying the site chronicling the Massachusetts senator's debunked Native American heritage claims violates the tech giant's rules against impersonation. Shares

House Democrats say Trump may have lied to Mueller: Report President Trump may have lied in his answers to special counsel Robert Mueller, lawyers for the House of Representatives reportedly alleged. Shares

Rep. Chris Collins resigns ahead of expected guilty plea for insider trading: Report Rep. Chris Collins of New York is expected this week to plead guilty to federal insider trading charges. Shares

Joe Biden holds big lead in South Carolina: Poll Even as other surveys show him slipping in some early states, former Vice President Joseph R. Biden holds a sizable advantage over the rest of the 2020 Democratic presidential field in South Carolina, home of the first-in-the-south primary, according to a CNN poll released on Sunday. Shares

Trump, Republicans move to discredit complaint from 'secondhand' whistleblower President Trump and his allies are deploying a new favorite word -- "secondhand" -- as they attempt to discredit a government official who blew the whistle on White House interactions with Ukraine, hoping the public will view Democrats' impeachment inquiry as a hasty mission built on hearsay. Shares

Fox's Chris Wallace criticizes 'astonishing and misleading' spin from Trump's supporters Fox News anchor Chris Wallace on Friday slammed the "deeply misleading" spin that defenders of President Trump are producing in the wake of the scandal with Ukraine. Shares

Hillary Clinton: 'Illegitimate president' Trump won't be reelected Hillary Clinton declared Donald Trump an "illegitimate president" and confidently predicted he would lose his 2020 reelection bid. Shares

Ukraine casts shadow over Biden campaign: 'If you are Elizabeth Warren, you have to be giddy' The Bidens' history in Ukraine is getting another look in the aftermath of a whistleblower complaint accusing President Trump of using threats to cut off U.S. military aid to pressure Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to investigate the Bidens and the son's profitable business dealings in Ukraine. Shares

Steve Bannon compares Pelosi's impeachment push to start of Civil War Stephen K. Bannon, President Trump's former chief strategist, compared the launch of an impeachment inquiry this week to the "shot at Fort Sumter" that started the Civil War. Shares

Joe Biden: Hard to avoid conclusion that Trump committed 'impeachable' offense Democratic presidential front-runner Joseph R. Biden on Wednesday said it's hard to avoid concluding that President Trump committed an "impeachable" offense. Shares

Al Franken to make return on weekly SiriusXM radio show Al Franken, who resigned his U.S. Senate seat in 2017 amid sexual misconduct charges, will re-emerge into the public sphere on Saturday when he starts a new weekly radio show on the SiriusXM satellite service. Shares

James Comey opposes Trump impeachment Opponents of impeaching President Trump include Sean Hannity, Kellyanne Conway ... and James Comey. Shares

Freshmen House Democrats: If true, Trump-Ukraine allegations would be 'impeachable offense' Seven freshmen House Democrats with national security backgrounds are now saying it would be an "impeachable offense" if President Trump did withhold military aid to Ukraine to try to get the country to dig up dirt on his political opponent. Shares

DNC rolls out criteria for November presidential debate The Democratic National Committee announced Monday that it was changing the criteria for candidates to qualify in the fifth 2020 presidential debate by putting a greater focus on early primary state polls. Shares

Stephanie Grisham says press briefings permanently canceled, cites behavior of reporters White House press secretary Stephanie Grisham confirmed Monday daily press briefings will not be reinstated under her leadership, citing the behavior of journalists who "weren't being good to" President Trump's administration. Shares

Feds rush to spend 20% of $500 billion in one month in 'use it or lose it' spending spree It's past time for some end-of-year fiscal restraint, said Sen. Joni Ernst, Iowa Republican. While debt hawks say they can end the "spend it while you have it" mentality with a simple legislative fix, nothing is simple in Washington. Shares

'Would serve no useful purpose': Alaska GOP cancels 2020 presidential primary The Alaska Republican Party has canceled holding a presidential primary in 2020. The party's State Central Committee passed a rule saying a primary "would serve no useful purpose" because Republican Donald Trump is president. Shares
description: The Washington Times offers unbiased coverage of political news from Washington, D.C., to politics around the nation.
